Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.”

 

  • It first affects the involuntary muscles first starting with the myocardium
  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis in voluntary muscles
  • Order of appearance of Rigor mortis in different organs:

questions.text: The method of autopsy carried out en masse to remove from tongue to prostate is? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Letulle technique

 

Letulle’s method (En masse)

 

  • Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • Best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other                         
  • Disadvantage: difficult to handle large mass.

 

Below image shows Letulle’s Method

 

 

Other Options:

 

Other Autopsy Techniques for Evisceration:

 

Option A. Virchow’s method

 

  • Each and every organ is removed one by one (e.g., each lung, each kidney, heart separately)
  • Relations of organs are not preserved
  • Most commonly used technique (easier to perform)

 

Below image shows Virchow’s Method

 

 

Option B. Rokitansky Method-

 

  • In situ
  • Organs dissected inside the body
  • for highly infectious disease, e.g., HIV to prevent the spread of infection

 

Below image shows Rokitansky Method

 

 

Option C. Ghon’s method (en block):

 

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks

 

Below image shows Ghon’s Method

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Letulle technique involves removing thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs en masse, preserving their relationships, and is preferred for infants to observe congenital abnormalities.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, PC dikshit, page 147

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer from a rural village in Southeast Asia presents to the clinic with complaints of painful black discoloration and ulcerations on his toes and feet. He reports that his symptoms began gradually and have worsened over the past few months. His medical history is unremarkable, but he mentions that he has been drinking well water from his local area for many years. Physical examination reveals signs of peripheral vascular insufficiency, with necrotic patches on his lower extremities suggestive of gangrene. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Arsenic poisoning

 

Explanation:

 

Arsenic poisoning, particularly due to chronic exposure through contaminated drinking water, is known to cause a condition called Blackfoot disease, an endemic peripheral vascular disease predominantly seen in specific regions such as the southwest coast of Taiwan. Chronic arsenic exposure leads to peripheral vascular damage, resulting in ischemia and gangrene of the lower extremities, which manifests as black discoloration of the feet, hence the name "Blackfoot." This condition is a severe form of peripheral vascular disease caused by long-term ingestion of arsenic-laden water, leading to progressive tissue necrosis and ulceration.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Thallium poisoning: Thallium poisoning can cause a range of symptoms, including hair loss, gastrointestinal disturbances, and neurological deficits. However, it does not specifically lead to peripheral gangrene or the characteristic black discoloration of the feet seen in Blackfoot disease.

 

B. Cadmium poisoning: Cadmium poisoning is primarily associated with renal damage, bone demineralization, and respiratory complications, especially from inhalation exposure. It does not cause peripheral vascular disease or gangrenous changes like those seen in arsenic-related Blackfoot disease.

 

D. Chromium poisoning: Chromium exposure, particularly hexavalent chromium, can cause respiratory symptoms, skin ulcers, and an increased risk of cancer but does not lead to the vascular damage and gangrenous changes characteristic of Blackfoot disease caused by arsenic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Blackfoot disease is a peripheral vascular disease caused by chronic exposure to high levels of arsenic, particularly in endemic regions where drinking water is contaminated. This condition results in severe ischemia and gangrene of the lower extremities, presenting as characteristic black discoloration and necrosis of the feet.

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female had a fight with her husband and was brought dead and an autopsy was performed to find the cause of death. Can you identify the probable cause of death from the image given below? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Throttling

 

The image shows bruises and abrasion on the neck which are strongly suggestive of throttling

 

Manual strangulation (throttling): Compression of neck by hands

 

Autopsy findings in Manual Strangulation (Throttling):

 

  • External findings on the neck:
    • Bruising on the neck. (Especially 6 penny bruises: These are bruises produced  The tips of the fingers, are oval or round and 1.5–2 cm in size)
    • Abrasions of the neck (especially crescent shaped abrasions produced by nails)

 

  • Internal findings in the neck
    • Internal Neck injuries are very significant in throttling like:
    • Extravasation of blood in subcutaneous tissues
    • Tear of platysma or sternomastoid muscles.
    • Hemorrhages in mucous membrane of larynx, epiglottis, and pharynx.
    • Inward compression fracture of hyoid bone
    • Fracture of superior horns of thyroid cartilage

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (Strangulation): Here the word “strangulation” implies ligature strangulation, because we have throttling in other choice. Ligature strangulation would have a ligature mark

 

Option C (Hanging): Hanging would have a ligature mark

 

Option D Mugging: Strangulation by holding the neck of victim in the bend of elbow or knee of assailant. Here the injuries (both internal and external) are minimal. There may be some diffuse abrasion / bruise externally, but it will not be as prominent and localized as shown in question.

 

 

Educational objective

 

Throttling is characterized by bruises and abrasions on the neck caused by manual compression, often accompanied by significant internal injuries.

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

 

  • Lot of blackening is easily visible around the firearm wound in the image.
  • Burning, blackening and tattooing are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds typically do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are generally larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds lack the features of burning, blackening, and tattooing. The wound edges are usually cleaner.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Similar to close shot exit wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not have burning, blackening, or tattooing and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: After visiting a village temple with his grandmother, a 5-year-old boy began crying intensely during the return trip. Within three hours, he was brought to the emergency department. He displayed symptoms such as altered consciousness, cold and sweaty extremities, heightened salivation, and excessive sweating. Physical examination revealed paleness and priapism, along with vital signs as follows: blood pressure of 140/78 mmHg, heart rate of 152 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 36 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. Considering his condition, what treatment approach would you choose for his management? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prazosin

 

This is a case of scorpion bite. The key characteristic feature of scorpion bite is autonomic storm, and sometimes cholinergic storm. This subject is having the features of both storms as described below.

 

Scorpion Toxins affect various ion channels. By acting on sodium (excitation) and potassium (blocking) channels, the toxin prolongs depolarization at postsynaptic postganglionic nerve terminals of ANS. This cause a massive release of sympathetic and parasympathetic mediators, resulting in mixed neuroexcitatory syndrome.

 

Clinical Manifestations of Scorpion bite: Main manifestation of scorpion bite is adrenergic (autonomic storm). Sometimes Cholinergic (muscarinic) storm occurs.

 

  • Adrenergic Storm: Overstimulation of sympathetic system result in “adrenergic storm” which consists of cardiac (tachycardia, peripheral vasoconstriction, hypertension, diaphoresis), metabolic (hyperthermia, hyperglycaemia), urogenital (urinary retention), respiratory (bronchial dilation, tachypnea), and neuromuscular (mydriasis, tremor, agitation, convulsions).

 

  • Cholinergic syndrome: Overstimulation of parasympathetic system result in a hypersecretion syndrome (salivation, sweating, vomiting, urinary incontinence, bronchial hypersecretion, and diarrhea), abdominal pain, miosis, bronchospasm, bradycardia with hypotension and, in the male, priapism.

 

Management:

 

  • Prazosin–a post-synaptic alpha1, adreno-receptor antagonist–is the first line of management. It suppresses sympathetic outflow and activates K channels.
  • Scorpion Antivenom: Scorpion venom act very fast. Anti-venom has to be given within 30 minutes of sting to be effective. So anti-venom is useful only in limited cases which present very early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Anti-snake venom: Not useful in scorpion bite

 

Option B) Methylprednisolone:  Steroids are not useful in scorpion bite, and moreover steroids might enhance the necrotizing effects of catecholamines on myocardium.

 

Option D) Adrenaline: It will further worsen autonomic storm

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the first-line treatment for scorpion envenomation due to its ability to suppress sympathetic outflow and mitigate the effects of the autonomic storm.

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine
Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the picture given below? (AIIMS May 2018,)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

The image shows aconite, a highly toxic plant. All parts of the aconite plant are poisonous, not just the roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Causes AV block: Correct statement. Aconite poisoning causes AV block due to its effects on the heart.

 

Option C. Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine: Correct statement. Atropine is used to counteract the bradycardia and AV block caused by aconite poisoning.

 

Option D. Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant: Correct statement. "Mitha zeher" is a common name for aconite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite:

 

  • All parts of the plant are poisonous.
  • Aconite is also called as - monkhood, mitha zeher, bish, and bikh.
  • Method of poisoning - It is a cardiac poison and causes AV block, bradycardia.
  • Treatment of choice - Atropine

questions.text: A young male presents with suspected poisoning and has pin-point pupils. Which of the following can be the poison.  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Opioid
 

 

Educational objective :

 

Pin-point pupils are a classic sign of opioid intoxication and are crucial for identifying opioid overdose in clinical settings. Opioids act by stimulating mu-receptors, leading to reduced sympathetic tone in the eye, which results in constricted pupils.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was taken by her neighbour to the emergency department after an incident involving her husband. She reported that during a domestic altercation, her husband swung an axe at her left arm. Upon examination, a significant injury was observed on her upper left arm. The wound appeared deep, with jagged and irregular edges. The surrounding area showed signs of bruising. Based on the clinical scenario, what type of wound is likely to be present on the patient's upper left arm? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chop wound 

 

A heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, e.g. axe produces chop wounds. Chop wounds have features of both sharp and blunt force injuries. They are characterized by deep, jagged, and irregular edges with surrounding bruising.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incised wound:

 

  • Produced by lighter weapons like knife, blades etc.
  • Margins are not contused and abraded. 
  • Destruction of underlying tissues is less as compared to cop wound.

 

Option C. Lacerated wound:

 

  • Lacerations can result from accidents, falls, or impact with blunt objects.
  • Lacerated wounds are not clean cut, whereas incised and chop wounds are clean cut.

 

Option D. Abrasion:  In abrasions only the superficial skin is damaged. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cut laceration / chop wounds: 

 

  • Produced by a heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, E.g. axe, chopper
    • It has features of both blunt force (bruised and abraded margins, irregular margins) and sharp force (clean margins)
    • A deep and wide cut over the body tissues.
    • Marked destruction of underlying tissues
    • Below image shows chop wound by axe:

questions.text: Which Section of the IPC deals with the punishment of perjury? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 193

 

Perjury (false evidence) means intentional making of a false statement by a person who was under a legal obligation (e.g. under oath) to speak the truth.

 

Section 193 IPC (Now, BNS 229): Punishment for Perjury (false evidence). Specifies the punishment for giving false evidence under oath, which can be up to 7 years of imprisonment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 191: Defines the act of giving false evidence under oath but does not specify the punishment. (BNS 227)

 

Option B. 192: Deals with the fabrication of false evidence but not directly related to perjury. (BNS 228)

 

Option D. 197: Deals with issuing false certificates and provides the same punishment as perjury, up to 7 years, but it is not specifically for perjury. (BNS 234)

 

Educational Objective:

 

IPC related to false evidence:

 

191 IPC: Definition of Perjury (false evidence): Giving false evidence under oath

 

193 IPC: Punishment for Perjury (false evidence): up to 7 years

 

197 IPC: Issuing false certificates- same punishment as that of false evidence (upto 7 years)

 

201 IPC: Causing disappearance of evidence of offence or giving false information to screen offender: Upto 07 years. (BNS 238)

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 12-16

 

Fingerprints begin to form between 12 to 16 weeks of intrauterine life. By this stage, the basic patterns of the ridges on the skin are established. The formation continues, and fingerprints are complete by approximately 24 weeks of intrauterine life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.

questions.text: A rape victim is brought to the casualty of a government hospital for examination. Within what time should a vaginal swab be taken to look for the presence of spermatozoa? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Within 72 hours

 

Spermatozoa can be demonstrated only if a vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours of an assault.

 

Semen can be demonstrated on evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing upto 96 hours.

 

Educational Objective

 

Presence of spermatozoa and other microorganisms

 

•Spermatozoa remain motile in the vagina for 6-8 hours, occasionally up to 12 hours.

•Nonmotile forms can be detected for about 24 hours, rarely up to 48-72 hours.

•Detection involves aspirating vaginal contents and examining under a microscope.

•Motile sperms suggest recent intercourse; nonmotile sperms indicate a broader time frame (12-72 hours).

•Intact spermatozoa are rarely found in the vagina after 72 hours.

•Seminal fluid detection from vasectomized males requires prostatic acid phosphatase demonstration.

•P30, a semen-specific glycoprotein, is used as a screening test, detectable in vaginal fluid for about 27 hours.

questions.text: What is the cause of tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Unburnt particles  

 

  • Tattooing is a term used to describe the punctate abrasions observed when skin comes into contact with partially burned or unburned grains of gunpowder.
  • They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing
  • They are seen in near (30-50cm) to mid-range of shooting

 

Firearm injuries:

 

 

Blackening – due to deposit of smoke

 

 

 

Grease collar - due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues

 

Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smoke: Causes blackening, not tattooing.

 

Option C. Impact: Refers to the force of the bullet causing tissue damage but does not explain tattooing.

 

Option D. Muzzle impression: Occurs when the muzzle of the firearm makes contact with the skin, leaving an impression, but does not cause tattooing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is caused by unburnt particles of gunpowder embedding into the skin.

questions.text: The term "St. Anthony's Fire" is historically associated with poisoning by which of the following substances? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Ergot alkaloids

 

Explanation:

 

St. Anthony's Fire is an archaic term used to describe ergotism, a condition resulting from long-term poisoning with ergot alkaloids. These alkaloids are produced by the fungus Claviceps purpurea, which commonly infects rye and other grains. Ergotism is characterized by a range of symptoms, including vasoconstriction, hallucinations, and gangrene.

 

Other Options:

  • b. Spanish fly: Spanish fly (cantharidin) is a toxic substance derived from blister beetles, causing severe irritation and blistering of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • c. Crotalaria juncea: This plant contains pyrrolizidine alkaloids, which can cause liver damage and pulmonary hypertension.
  • d. Aflatoxin: Aflatoxins are produced by certain molds and are potent carcinogens. They primarily affect the liver and can lead to liver cancer.

 

Educational Objective

 

St. Anthony's Fire is a historical term synonymous with ergotism, a condition caused by ergot alkaloid poisoning. Recognizing this association is important for understanding the historical context of this condition.

questions.text: A man running a 40-kilometre marathon on a hot summer afternoon suddenly collapsed before completing his race. On examination, his body temperature was 104 degrees, but there were no physical signs of dehydration. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

The case scenario is suggestive of a heatstroke in this patient. Heatstroke / heat exhaustion occurs when the body can no longer control its temperature. The body's temperature rises rapidly, the sweating mechanism fails, and the body is unable to cool down. When heat stroke occurs, the body temperature can rise to 106°F or higher within 10 to 15 minutes.

 

In this case it is due to prolonged exposure to the sun during running.

 

Management - Rapidly cooling the body with cold blankets till temperature falls below 102 degrees Celsius.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot skin: Likely to be present due to the high body temperature in heatstroke.

 

Option B. Hypotension: Can be seen due to vasodilation and possible dehydration.

 

Option D. Disorientation: Likely due to neurological dysfunction caused by the extreme heat affecting the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the following post-mortem change. (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Suggillation

 

The image shows post mortem staining on the back, also called suggillation. Post-mortem staining (PMS) is the settling of the blood in the dependent portions of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish-red discoloration of the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tattooing: Tattoos appear as distinct, well-defined patterns or designs, often in various colors. Tattoos can be located anywhere on the body and are not necessarily confined to dependent areas. They are typically intentional markings made by injecting ink into the skin.

 

Option C. Putrefaction: The body becomes greenish in colour in putrefaction. Later it becomes blackish.

 

Option D. Decomposition: Same explanation as that of putrefaction

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Mortem Staining (PMS)

 

  •  It is the settling of the blood in the dependent, portion of the body after death due to loss of circulation, causing a purplish red discoloration of the skin.
  • Other names of PMS are:
    • Hypostasis
    • livor mortis
    • Vibices
    • Suggillation
    • Postmortem Lividity
    • Cadaveric lividity
    • Darkening of death
  •  It is present on dependent areas, but absent on pressure areas as the blood vessels get compressed. In a supine body the pressure areas are back of chest, buttocks etc as these are in the direct contact with ground.

questions.text:
Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis?

 

  1. Triangular obturator foramen

  2. U-shaped pubic angle

  3. Everted ischial tuberosity

  4. Large greater sciatic notch

  5. Large acetabulum

  6. Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only 5   

 

Large acetabulum: The acetabulum in males is generally larger to support a greater range of motion and the weight of a more muscular body.

 

Other Features:

 

1. Triangular obturator foramen: Typically seen in males.

 

2. U-shaped pubic angle: This is more characteristic of the female pelvis, which has a wider pubic angle to facilitate childbirth.

 

3. Everted ischial tuberosity: This is more common in females.

 

4. Large greater sciatic notch: More pronounced in females.

 

6. Deep preauricular sulcus: More commonly seen in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between male and female pelvis

choices.text: Residual from barrel of gun
Gutter fracture of skull

questions.text: What is bullet wipe? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Residual from barrel of gun

 

Explanation:

 

A "bullet wipe" is a gray or black ring around an entrance bullet hole. The ring is formed by bullet lubricant, byproducts of propellant, traces of bullet metal, and residue in the gun barrel from previous use. It is caused due to residue from barrel of the gun.

 

Other options

 

Option B) Blackening: It occurs due to combustion (smoke) produced by burning of gun powder when a firearm is fired.

 

Option C) Gutter fracture of skull: It occurs due to a bullet passing adjacent to the skull

 

Option D) Tattooing: It occurs due to unburnt gun powder particles which gets deposited around the firearm wound.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bullet Wipe (Grease/Dirt Collar)

 

• Black/gray ring around gunshot wound.

• Composition includes bullet lubrication, paraffin, lead, barrel debris, and gun oil.

• Wider side of the ring indicates the direction of fire.

• More noticeable in shots from freshly oiled weapons.

• It  is dark in the center, fading towards the periphery.

• Prominent in clothing, termed as ‘bullet wipe.’

• It serve as proof of an entry wound in forensic analysis.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Marbling

 

  • The post mortem change shown above is marbling.

  • In marbling, blood vessels are visible on the skin as greenish-black streaks and eventually results in skin discoloration ranging from green to black, due to the formation of sulphmethemoglobin, which starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postmortem lividity: This is the settling of blood in the lower parts of the body after death, causing a purplish-red discoloration. It does not produce the distinct streaks seen in marbling.

 

Option C. Filigree burns: These are burns that produce a lace-like pattern on the skin, usually caused by electrical injuries. They do not match the appearance shown in the image.

 

Option D. Subcutaneous emphysema: This occurs when air is trapped under the skin, often due to trauma or infection, leading to a characteristic crackling sensation when pressed. It does not produce the streaked pattern seen in marbling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling is a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black streaks on the skin due to the formation of sulfhemoglobin, becoming prominent 24-48 hours after death.

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common habit-forming drug is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heroin

 

Heroin is an opioid and is the most commonly abused opioid. Heroin has the highest dependence potential among all drugs listed. It is highly addictive, and users can develop a strong physical dependence, leading to withdrawal symptoms if the drug is not taken.

 

Most commonly abused drugs: This can vary from one country to another. Generally, alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, opioids are most commonly abused drugs:

 

  • Alcohol is the most common Used/Abused Substance in the World
  • Tobacco is the most common Used/Abused Substance in India
  • Cannabis is the most common “illegally” used drug in India as well as world, though its dependence potential is relatively lower.
  • Heroin is the most commonly abused opioid, and is the drug with highest dependence potential amongst all the drugs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming.

 

Option C. LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen. It can be abused, but it does not have the same level of physical dependence potential.

 

Option D. Phencyclidine (PCP): PCP is a dissociative drug with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming drug.

 

Educational Objective

 

Common habit-forming drugs:

 

  • Cannabis
  • Opioids
  • Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • Ecstasy
  • Cocaine

 

Heroin is the most common drug which is habit forming or in other words can cause physical dependence in which a patient gets withdrawal if he does not take the drug.

questions.text: In a gunshot case, blackening is noted surrounding a firearm entry wound. Blackening occurs mainly due to: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D. Black smoke particles

 

Blackening around the entry wound is primarily due to the deposition of smoke and soot produced from the burning propellant (gunpowder). This is most notable at close range and creates a dark mark surrounding the entry site.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat Fire Effect : This involves the heat generated by the discharge of a firearm. It can cause singeing of the hair and possibly burning of the skin around the wound, but it does not usually cause blackening.

 

Option B. Muzzle of Firearm Weapon : This refers to the end of the gun barrel. While the muzzle is close to the skin, it may deposit soot and cause burns, but it is not itself a cause of blackening. It's more about proximity effects.

 

Option C. Unburnt Gunpowder Particles : When a gun is fired, unburnt particles of gunpowder can exit the muzzle along with the bullet. These particles can cause stippling or tattooing around the wound, which is not the same as blackening but related to small abrasions on the skin.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of blackening, soot, and unburnt gunpowder at a gunshot entry wound provides crucial information about the distance and angle of the shot.

questions.text: Pick the mechanism of death in cold water drowning? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vagal inhibition

 

  • In cold water drowning cause of death is Cold shock response/ hydrocution / immersion syndrome.
  • It is a series of neurogenic cardio-respiratory responses caused by sudden immersion in cold water.
  • Death results from vagal inhibition of the heart, i.e., cardiac arrest occurring due to increased stimulation of the vagus nerve by
  • Sudden entry of water into the nasopharynx or larynx
  • Diving into the water in a manner that is suddenly strikes the abdomen
  • Sudden in-rush of cold water into the ears

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asphyxia: Common in other types of drowning but not the primary cause in cold water drowning.

 

Option B. Laryngeal spasm: Can contribute to asphyxia but is not the primary mechanism in cold water drowning.

 

Option D. Cardiac arrest: While cardiac arrest occurs, it is due to vagal inhibition, not directly from cold water exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cold water drowning, the primary cause of death is vagal inhibition, leading to cardiac arrest due to the sudden stimulation of the vagus nerve from cold water immersion.

choices.text: Anterior transmural
Posterior transmural

questions.text: Which of the following myocardial infarcts cause aneurysm as a post-MI complication? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior transmural

 

As a post-MI complication, anterior transmural infarcts contribute to aneurysm formation.

 

Myocardial infarction (MI) complications such left ventricular aneurysms (LVAs) and pseudoaneurysms can cause mortality or severe morbidity. The most frequent outcome of MI is an LVA, which typically involves the anterior wall.

 

Conduction blockages, right ventricular involvement, or both are more likely to make posterior transmural infarcts problematic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subendocardial: These infarcts affect only the innermost layers of the heart wall and do not typically cause aneurysms.

 

Option C. Posterior transmural: While serious and affecting the full thickness of the heart wall, posterior infarcts are less likely than anterior infarcts to result in aneurysm formation due to the smaller area typically involved and differing hemodynamic forces.

 

Option D. Inferior wall: Inferior MIs can lead to complications like arrhythmias or heart block but are less commonly associated with aneurysm formation compared to anterior transmural MIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior transmural myocardial infarctions are most commonly associated with the formation of left ventricular aneurysms due to the location, extent of myocardial damage, and the dynamics of ventricular pressure that exacerbate the risk of wall outpouching and aneurysm development in this region.

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hand, foot, and mouth disease

 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease.

 

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness that presents as a vesicular eruption in the mouth, but it can also involve the hands, feet, buttocks, and/or genitalia. Caused by Coxsackie A virus. The presence of vesicular rashes in these specific locations is a hallmark of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. In Dengue Fever, the initial rash is a transient flushing erythema of face that typically occurs shortly before or within the first 24-48 hours of the onset of symptoms and is thought to be the result of capillary dilatation. The second rash usually occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and it is characterized by asymptomatic maculopapular or morbilliform eruption.

 

Option C. The rash associated with the Zika virus is a combination of flat blotches (macules) and raised tiny reddish bumps like papules (not as petechiae)

 

Option D. In roseola infantum, upon rapid defervescence of the fever around days three to five, small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules will develop. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. The rash is typically nonpruritic, blanching and can persist from one to two days. Caused by HHV 6.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vesicular rash is specifically seen in Hand, foot, and mouth disease, which is caused by Coxsackie A virus.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man from a rural area of Bihar presents to the outpatient department of a tertiary care hospital in Patna. He has been experiencing fever for the past week, associated with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and palpable lymphadenopathy. Despite being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and antimalarial agents by a local practitioner, there's been no significant relief. Blood investigations for typhoid (Widal test) are negative; however, the rk39 dipstick test is positive. Based on the clinical picture and the diagnostic findings, what would be the most appropriate drug of choice for the treatment of his condition? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Liposomal Amphotericin B

 

  • This clinical presentation strongly indicates the diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis.
  • The recommended course of action for this patient involves the administration of liposomal amphotericin B.

 

 

Incubation Period: 10 days to 2 years (average 1 – 4 months)

 

Serological tests:

 

  • ELISA: for diagnosis as well as epidemiological field survey
  • rk 39 dipstick test
  • Indirect Flourescent Antibody Test (IFAT)
  • Direct Agglutination Test

 

 Treatment of Leishmaniasis

 

  • Sodium stibogluconate
  • Miltefosine
  • Paramomycin
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (DOC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Fluconazole is an anti-fungal, not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

 

Option C: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA

 

Option D: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala Azar) should be treated with liposomal amphotericin B, especially when diagnosed with a positive rk39 dipstick test.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td

 

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

 

  • Capsulorrhexis is a step in the conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) method.
  • It is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens.
  • Anterior capsulotomy can be done by 3 methods:
    1. Can-opener's technique
    2. Linear capsulotomy or envelope technique
    3. Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis
  • Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered superior because it does not leave any edges or tears when done correctly.
  • Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility during the procedure.
  • In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex while leaving the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact.
  • After capsulorrhexis, hydro dissection is performed using a balanced salt solution to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule.
  • Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted, and the incision is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrodissection: Hydrodissection involves injecting fluid under the anterior capsule to separate the lens nucleus from the cortex and the capsule. This procedure follows capsulorrhexis and serves to facilitate the removal of the lens material. The image does not show fluid injection or the separation process typical of hydrodissection.

 

Option C. Intraocular lens implantation: This step involves placing an intraocular lens (IOL) into the capsular bag once the lens material has been removed. In the image, there is no indication of an IOL being handled or inserted, as the focus is solely on manipulating the capsule itself, which precedes the IOL implantation in the surgical sequence.

 

Option D. Lens aspiration: Lens aspiration involves the removal of the lens cortex and nucleus, usually through suction or phacoemulsification, following the capsulorrhexis and hydrodissection steps. The image does not depict any equipment or actions associated with the aspiration of lens material, such as a phacoemulsification handpiece or suction device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capsulorrhexis is characterized by the creation of a controlled and continuous tear in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is essential for accessing and removing the lens material in cataract surgery. This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department unconscious and without any identification. A non-contrast CT scan reveals hydrocephalus requiring immediate neurosurgical intervention to save the patient's life. Under which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) can the neurosurgeon proceed with the surgery without obtaining informed consent? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Section 92

 

Explanation:

 

Section 92 of the Indian Penal Code provides a legal framework for acting in good faith to save a person's life, even without their consent, when it is impossible to obtain consent and the action is intended to prevent death or grievous harm. In this scenario, the patient's altered mental state prevents them from providing informed consent, and the urgent nature of the hydrocephalus necessitates immediate intervention to save their life.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Section 87: This section deals with consent for acts not intended to cause death or grievous harm and is not applicable in this life-threatening situation.
  • Section 89: This section concerns consent for children under 12 or individuals of unsound mind, requiring guardian consent, which is not feasible in this emergency.
  • Section 90: This section defines when consent is invalid (e.g., given under fear or misconception), but it does not provide an exception for emergency situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Section 92 of the IPC allows healthcare providers to act in good faith to save a person's life in emergencies where obtaining consent is impossible, provided the action is taken to prevent death or serious harm.

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of high-grade fever & altered sensorium. He was diagnosed to be suffering from meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical treatment? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone

 

Ceftriaxone or cefotaxime is the drug of choice for empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. However, Penicillin G remains the antibiotic of choice for susceptible strains.

 

Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated in with patients with suspected bacterial meningitis before the results of CSF Gram stain and culture are known.

 

S. pneumoniae and N. meningitidis are the most common etiologic organism of community acquired bacterial meningitis. Due to the emergence of penicillin resistant and cephalosporin resistant S. pneumoniae, empirical therapy of community acquired suspected bacterial meningitis should include a combination of –

 

  • Dexamethasone
  • Third or fourth generation cephalosporin (E.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime or Cefepime)
  • Vancomycin
  • Acyclovir- HSV Encephalitis is the main differential
  • Doxycycline –during tick season

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penicillin G: While effective against Neisseria meningitidis, it is not the first choice for empirical treatment due to broader resistance concerns and coverage needs in initial therapy settings.

 

Option C. Cefotetan and D. Cefoxitin: These are second-generation cephalosporins, which are not typically used for the treatment of meningococcal meningitis due to insufficient CNS penetration and coverage compared to third-generation cephalosporins like ceftriaxone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ceftriaxone is the preferred empirical therapy for meningococcal meningitis due to its effective CNS penetration, broad antibacterial coverage, and favorable dosing regimen. Immediate initiation of empirical therapy is crucial in suspected bacterial meningitis to prevent severe outcomes.

questions.text: Based on the symptoms reported by the patient, what could be the possible diagnosis for a 30-year-old man who has been experiencing recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for the past four years? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fistula in ano

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract or channel that develops between the anal canal and the skin around the anus.
  • It is usually caused by an infected anal gland or abscess that fails to heal.
  • The symptoms of a fistula in ano may include pain, swelling, discharge of pus or blood, and recurrent abscesses around the anus.
  • Diagnosis of a fistula in ano is typically made by a physical examination and medical history review.
  • Imaging studies such as MRI or ultrasound may also be used to determine the extent and location of the fistula.
  • Given the patient's chronic history of recurrent discharge and pain around the anus for four years, a fistula in ano is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pilonidal sinus: A pilonidal sinus is a small cyst or abscess that occurs in the cleft at the top of the natal cleft. It often contains hair and skin debris. Common symptoms include pain, redness, and swelling in the area of the buttocks crease, and sometimes it can release pus. Given that the patient's symptoms are around the anus and involve recurrent discharge and pain for several years, a pilonidal sinus, which primarily occurs in the cleft of the buttocks, is less likely.

 

Option B. Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infective gangrene seen on the back or chest wall. Carbuncles can lead to the formation of an abscess, and symptoms might include a lump filled with pus, which might weep or ooze. While carbuncles can form on any part of the body, their acute and more widespread nature differs from the chronic, recurrent discharge around the anus described by the patient.

 

Option C. Boil: A boil, or furuncle, is a skin infection that starts in a hair follicle or oil gland. It typically starts as a reddened and tender area, which becomes hard and then softens as it fills with pus. Boils can occur anywhere on the body, but they're more common on the face, neck, armpits, buttocks, and thighs. Again, given the chronic and recurrent nature of the patient's symptoms specifically around the anus, a singular boil wouldn't match this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A fistula in ano is an abnormal tract that typically develops between the anal canal and the perianal skin, usually due to a previously untreated or inadequately treated abscess.
  • The chronic and recurrent nature of symptoms like discharge and pain around the anus is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scaphoid fracture

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Scaphoid is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children.
  • Scaphoid fracture is seen most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30.
  • Middle third (waist) fractures are most common accounting for 70% of scaphoid fractures > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%), in adults and adolescents.
  • Distal pole avulsion type fracture is most common fracture type in children.
  • Salient Features:
    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.
    • A delay in diagnosis and treatment of this fracture may alter the prognosis for union.
    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possibe fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.
    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.
  • Radiological Investigations:
    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.
    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.
    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.
  • Management:
    • Non-displaced, stable scaphoid fractures: Scaphoid glass holding cast

 

  • Displaced, unstable scaphoid fractures: Headless screw (Herbert) is used
  • Complication: Non-union > Avascular necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trans-scaphoid perilunate disruption fracture. Trans-scaphoid fracture-dislocation is an unusual traumatic injury mainly seen in young patients due to high energy trauma. These dislocations may be missed in 25% of cases. If it is neglected, it leads to progress of carpal instability and post-traumatic arthritis. The treatment aims at reducing dislocation, internally fixing fracture, and repairing ligament injuries. In the acute period, there is pain and swelling over the hand and wrist, and gross deformity of the wrist can be noted. Evidence of median nerve injury is common. Acute carpal tunnel syndrome is observed in about 25% of patients. Radiographs of the contralateral wrist for comparison can be helpful to confirm scapholunate widening, also called a ‘Terry Thomas sign.’

 

 

 

Terry Thomas Sign

 

Option C. Hook of hamate fracture. Hook of hamate fractures are rare, often missed injuries generally as a result of a direct blow to the hamate bone. It is most commonly seen in athletes. Mechanism of injury is a direct blow to the volar proximal palm. Ulnar-sided wrist pain is the most common complaint, hypothenar pain, pain with activities requiring tight grip. On examination, there is limited ulnar deviation and decreased grip strength. Diagnosis is confirmed with radiographic carpal tunnel view or CT scan. Treatment is either observation, surgical excision, or surgical fixation depending on the severity of the symptoms and activity demands of the patient.

 

 

Option D. Distal radius fracture. Distal radius fractures are the most common injury, resulting from fall on an outstretched hand. It is more common in older patients with osteoporosis due to fall. The patient presents with wrist pain, swelling, and deformity.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray, mechanism of injury, and presenting complaints of the patient points towards the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture.

choices.text: Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°C with a shelf life of 5 days
Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15 °C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15° C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Platelets is stored between 20° C to 24° C with a shelf life of 5 days

 

Platelets can be stored at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 24°C, and they have a shelf life of 5 days (with continuous agitation) 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°C with a shelf life of 6 months: This statement is incorrect because cryoprecipitate is typically stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C with a shelf life of 1 year. Cryoprecipitate is rich in clotting factors like fibrinogen, Factor VIII, and von Willebrand factor.

 

Option C. Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol, and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks: This statement is incorrect. Packed red blood cells stored with solutions like SAGM (Saline, Adenine, Glucose, Mannitol) are typically stored at temperatures between 2°C to 6°C, not -5°C to -15°C, and they have a shelf life of up to 42 days, not 5 weeks.

 

Option D. Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years: This statement is incorrect. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is usually stored at temperatures between -18°C to -30°C and has a shelf life of 1 year.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-coagulants solution and shelf life

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used to assess the extent of drug absorption in a plasma concentration vs. time graph? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Area under the curve

 

In the Concentration-time curve for a given drug, the area under the curve (AUC) tells us about the bioavailability of the drug.

 

The bioavailability of a given drug is defined as the fraction of the given dose that reaches the systemic circulation.

 

It depends on 2 factors:

 

1.Absorption of the drug (More the extent of absorption of the drug, greater is the bioavailability)

 

2.First pass metabolism of the drug (More the first pass metabolism of a drug, lesser is its bioavailability).

 

So, in other words, the AUC tells us about the extent of absorption of the drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax: The time to reach the maximum concentration (Cmax) in plasma. It indicates the rate of absorption but not the extent of absorption.

 

Option B. Cmax: The maximum concentration of the drug in plasma. It provides information on the peak level achieved but does not reflect the overall extent of absorption.

 

Option C. T1/2: The half-life of the drug, which is the time it takes for the plasma concentration to reduce by half. This parameter is related to the duration of action and elimination of the drug, not the extent of absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Area Under the Curve (AUC) in a plasma concentration vs. time graph is used to assess the extent of drug absorption, reflecting the bioavailability of the drug in the systemic circulation.

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

 

 

 

The red shaded area in the given image indicates a portion of the lateral medulla. The blood supply to this area is provided by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery. This area is typically involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

 

  • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA): This artery is a branch of the vertebral artery and supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. Damage to this artery can lead to lateral medullary syndrome, characterized by various neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior cerebellar artery: This artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and does not supply the lateral medulla.

 

Option B. Posterior cerebral artery: This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, not the lateral medulla.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: While the basilar artery gives rise to the superior cerebellar artery and the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, it does not directly supply the lateral medulla. The vertebral arteries, which form the basilar artery, give rise to PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

choices.text: Soft wrist and ankle restraints

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is found in a compromised position during a police raid, restrained in a manner that limits her ability to move her arms and legs independently, check the image shown below. The officers recognize this as a dangerous form of restraint that can severely restrict breathing and cause significant distress. What type of physical restraint is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Hog tying

 

Explanation:

 

Hog tying is a form of physical restraint where a person’s hands are tied behind their back, their feet are bound, and the hand and foot restraints are connected behind the back. This position severely restricts movement and can impair breathing, leading to positional asphyxia, which can be fatal. It is often considered a form of excessive force and has been associated with significant physical and psychological harm. Hog tying is also recognized as a method of torture due to its restrictive nature and the potential to cause severe distress and injury.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Four-point restraint: This restraint method involves securing both arms and legs to separate points, typically in a medical setting, such as a bed, to prevent self-harm or aggression. It does not involve coupling the hands and feet behind the back, making it less restrictive compared to hog tying.

 

B. Chair restraint: Chair restraints secure an individual to a chair, immobilizing the arms, legs, and torso with straps. It provides control without the severe positional risks associated with hog tying.

D. Soft wrist and ankle restraints: These restraints are commonly used in clinical settings to prevent patients from harming themselves. They allow limited movement and do not involve the hazardous coupling of hands and feet behind the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hog tying is a hazardous restraint technique where hands and feet are bound together behind the back, posing severe risks such as positional asphyxia. It is recognized as a form of torture, similar to other inhumane methods like Wet submarino (suffocation in liquids), Dry submarino (plastic bag suffocation), Telefono (ear beating), Falanga (foot beating), Parrot’s perch (upside-down suspension), Planton (prolonged standing), Saw horse (sitting on sharp objects), Ghotna (rolling a log over legs), Chepuwa (log compression on legs), Black slave (hot metal rod in the anus), and Electric cattle prod (applying electric current to sensitive areas). These methods are extremely cruel and pose significant dangers to the victim.

questions.text: All of the following muscles are derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch, except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Levator veli palatini

 

Levator veli palatini: The muscle responsible for elevating the soft palate, playing an essential role in swallowing. It prevents food and liquids from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing. This muscle is not derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch but from the 4th pharyngeal arch. It is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus, with contributions primarily from the vagus nerve (CN X).

 

First pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

 

  • Muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, lateral and medial pterygoids)
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani
  • Tensor velipalatini and
  • Anterior 2/3 of tongue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial pterygoids: It is one of the muscles of mastication which assists in elevating the mandible and plays a role in the side-to-side movement of the jaw. It originates from the medial pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone and inserts into the medial surface of the mandible. The medial pterygoid is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Lateral pterygoids: Like the medial pterygoid, it is also a muscle of mastication which depresses the mandible and side-to-side jaw movements. The muscle has two heads, superior and inferior, and it inserts into the neck of the mandible and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. Derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch, it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option D. Tensor veli palatini: It is responsible for tensing the soft palate and assists in opening the auditory (Eustachian) tube, equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the nasopharynx. This muscle is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is unique among the palatal muscles because it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Researcher was studying the effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and change in pH on ventilation, when he simulated the condition of hypoxia and hypercapnia with pH of 7.35 and plotted the graph, which one of the following is the appropriate representation of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

 

  • Curve A shows linear relationship between PCO2 and Ventilation i.e hypercapnia (↑PCO2) → ↑ Ventilation
  • Curve B shows effect of hypoxia and hypercapnia on Ventilation i.e when both Hypercapnia and Hypoxia (↑PCO2 & ↓O2) are present simultaneously but the pH is normal (unchanged)à slope of the curve also changes hence as a result curve becomes Steeper
  • Curve C shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis on Ventilation i.e. when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are present simultaneously → not only the slope of the curve changes but also the Shift of Apneic Point (point denoting PCO2 Levels Below which apnea i.e stoppage of breathing occurs) is seen.
  • Curve D also shows effect of hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (but in the question pH is Normal 7.35 ) on Ventilation i.e., when hypoxia, hypercapnia and acidosis (↑PCO2, ↓O2, ↓pH) are more severe à the slope of the curve will be more steeper with the Shift of Apneic Point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Curve B represents the condition of simultaneous hypoxia and hypercapnia with normal pH, showing a steeper slope in the relationship between PCO2 and ventilation.

choices.text: New drug application is filed after phase 4
Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance
Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding
Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding clinical trials? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Phase 4 is also called post-marketing surveillance

 

Phase 4 clinical trials are also called post-marketing surveillance. This statement is correct. Phase 4 trials are conducted after a drug has been approved and marketed to monitor its long-term effectiveness and safety.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. New drug application is filed after phase 4: This statement is incorrect. The New Drug Application (NDA) is filed after successful completion of Phase 3 clinical trials, not Phase 4. Phase 4 occurs after the drug has been approved and marketed.

 

Option C. Phase 3 are open label studies without any blinding: This statement is incorrect. Phase 3 clinical trials are typically randomized and double-blinded to eliminate bias and ensure robust results. Open label studies, where both the participants and investigators know which treatment is being administered, are less common in Phase 3 trials.

 

Option D. Phase 2 is done on healthy individuals: This statement is incorrect. Phase 2 clinical trials are conducted on patients who have the condition that the drug is intended to treat. Phase 1 trials, on the other hand, are usually done on healthy volunteers to assess safety and dosage.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with normal bone mineral density. X-ray is given below. Identify the diagnosis: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

SCURVY

 

  • It is the deficiency of vitamin C, causing defect in the osteoid formation. 
  • The rosary found in this condition is sharp and tender. 
  • Radiological Features: 
    • Sclerosed Margins of Epiphysis
    • Osteopenia – ground glass appearance – 1st sign – thinning of cortex (pencil thin cortex).
    • Metaphysis maybe deformed or fractured.
    • Frankel’s line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width and opacity) due to failure of resorption of calcified cartilage and stands out compared to the severely osteopenic metaphysis.
    • Scurvy line or scorbutic zone (Trummerfeld’s zone) – radiolucent transverse band adjacent to the dense provisional zone.
    • Margins of the epiphysis appears sclerotic, termed as ringing of epiphyses or Wimberger’s sign (Ring sign).
    • Lateral metaphyseal spur (Pelkan spur) at ends of metaphysis is produced by outward projection of zone of provisional calcification and periosteal reaction.
    • Corner or angle sign is peripheral metaphyseal cleft.
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage in lower end of femur and tibia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets. In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones. There is irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis, and thin and weak new trabeculae. On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped. The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance); and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis. Also called as marble bone disease, it is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen. 

 

 

 

Option D. Metaphyseal dysplasia. Also known as Pyle disease, it is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by flaring of the ends of long bones with relative constriction and sclerosis of the diaphysis and mild cranial sclerosis. The flared metaphyses are relatively lucent. The patients are often asymptomatic, although genu valgus deformity may be a feature. Patients present with short-limb dwarfism characterized by coxa vara, and spinal abnormalities. Radiographs reveals bulbous expansion of metaphysis. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image in the question is suggestive of features due to vitamin C deficiency, scurvy. 
  • Following are the features seen in a patient with scurvy on a plain radiograph:

choices.text: 20.8 hours
6.9 hours
13.8 hours

questions.text: The elimination rate constant of a drug is 0.05 hr. What is its half-life? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 13.8 hours

 

  • Half-life is the time in which the plasma concentration of the drug becomes half.
  • The elimination rate constant of a drug reflects the fraction of drug that is removed from the body compartment per unit time.
  • The elimination rate constant = k = 0.05 hr.
  • Half-life = t1/2 = 0.693/k
  • Therefore t1/2 = 0.693/0.05 =13.8 hrs.
     

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of a drug with an elimination rate constant of 0.05 hr is 13.8 hours, calculated using the formula t1/2=0.693/k

questions.text: A case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is detected to have metastasis in the lungs. It is considered as stage? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) III

 

Gestational trophoblastic neoplasms (GTN) are classified into stages based on their extent of spread:

 

  • Stage I: The disease is confined to the uterus.
  • Stage II: The disease has spread outside the uterus but remains confined to the genital structures.
  • Stage III: The disease has metastasized to the lungs, which is a significant indicator of progression beyond the local genital structures.
  • Stage IV: The disease has spread to other distant sites beyond the lungs, such as the liver or brain.

 

Since the case involves metastasis specifically to the lungs, it falls into Stage III, which is characterized by such pulmonary involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastasis to the lungs in gestational trophoblastic neoplasm is classified as Stage III.

 

Ref: Page no 364, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vulval cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows a 4 cm × 5 cm irregular fungating lesion present on the left labium majus of the vulva. The most likely diagnosis is vulvar carcinoma.
  • Vulvar cancer is typically characterized by irregular, fungating, or ulcerative lesions on the vulva. These lesions can be painful and may bleed or discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval hematoma: Vulval hematomas may occur due to direct trauma or accidental injuries. They present as a localized collection of blood within the vulvar tissues, leading to swelling and bruising, but they do not typically form irregular fungating lesions.

 

Option B. Condyloma acuminata: Condyloma acuminata, also known as genital warts, are commonly caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

They appear as multiple, small, cauliflower-like growths and are not typically large, irregular, or fungating.

 

Option D. Bartholin cyst: A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland gets blocked due to infection, resulting in a buildup of glandular secretions.

 

It presents as a swelling on one side of the vaginal opening, but it is typically smooth and round, not irregular and fungating.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulvar cancer often presents as an irregular, fungating lesion on the vulva.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 337,338

choices.text: Immediately inform the police and delay medical treatment until legal proceedings
Perform medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) with the consent of the girl and her parents under the supervision of a gynecologist
Provide emotional counseling and reassurance
Offer information on adoption or foster care

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. Her parents report that she is 15 weeks pregnant following a sexual assault. Ultrasound confirms the pregnancy and shows signs of fetal distress. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Perform medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) with the consent of the girl and her parents under the supervision of a gynecologist

 

Explanation:

 

In this case, the patient is a minor who is 15 weeks pregnant as a result of sexual assault and presents with severe symptoms and fetal distress. The first priority in this situation is the girl's health and safety, particularly given the distress and trauma.

 

At 15 weeks gestation, medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) is legally permissible with the informed consent of both the minor and her parents or legal guardians. Fetal distress further supports the need for prompt intervention to prevent complications. Till 20 weeks the termination can be performed by one trained Medical Officer or Gynecologist in a medically safe environment.

 

Reporting the sexual assault to the authorities is required by law but should not delay necessary medical treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Immediately inform the police and delay medical treatment until legal proceedings: While it is essential to report the sexual assault, delaying medical care in favor of legal proceedings is inappropriate. Medical treatment should not be postponed in an emergency situation, especially when the health of the patient is at risk.

 

C. Provide emotional counseling and reassurance: Emotional support and counseling are important, but they are not substitutes for immediate medical intervention in the case of fetal distress and potential complications.

 

D. Offer information on adoption or foster care: Discussing adoption or foster care is not appropriate in this emergency situation. The focus should be on addressing the immediate medical needs of the patient.

 


Educational Objective:

questions.text: The mutations/changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enhancer deletion

 

Enhancer deletion does not convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene. On the contrary, deletion of an enhancer would likely reduce the expression of the gene, potentially reducing its oncogenic potential, rather than increasing it.

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Promoter insertion: Can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene by increasing gene transcription.

 

Option C. Gene amplification: Leads to an increased number of gene copies, enhancing gene product levels, and contributing to oncogenesis.

 

Option D. Point mutation: A common mechanism for converting proto-oncogenes to oncogenes by altering the protein product to make it constitutively active.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transformation of proto-oncogene (i.e., normal cell proliferation gene) to oncogenes (i.e., cancer cell proliferation gene) may occur by three mechanisms:

 

  1. Point mutations i.e., an alteration of a single base in the DNA chain. Eg:- RAS oncogene carried in many human tumors such as bladder cancer, pancreatic adenocarcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma. Point mutations, deletions, or insertions in the promoter region of a proto-oncogene that led to increased transcription. 
  2. Chromosomal translocations i.e., transfer of a portion of one chromosome carrying protooncogene to another chromosome and making it independent of growth controls.  Eg :- Philadelphia chromosome seen in 95% cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia in which c-ABL protooncogene on chromosome 9 is translocated to chromosome 22.
  3. Gene amplification i.e., increasing the number of copies of DNA sequence in protooncogene leading to increased mDNA and thus increased or overexpressed gene product. Eg:- Neuroblastoma having n-MYC HSR region,  ERB-B1 in breast and ovarian cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 549-551

questions.text:
What investigations would you recommend for a female patient who presents with a 4cm x 3cm irregular mass in the upper outer quadrant of the right breast and a palpated lymph node of 2cm in the right axilla, but no mass palpated in the opposite breast? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Bilateral Mammography
  2. PET Scan
  3. Biopsy of the breast mass
  4. USG guided biopsy of the lymph node
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

 

  • The clinical presentation indicates that the patient may have breast cancer with local spread but no distant metastasis. To further investigate this, it is recommended to conduct bilateral mammography, biopsy of the breast mass (Triple assessment), and USG-guided biopsy of the suspicious lymph node.
  • Diagnostic mammography is a useful tool for examining women with abnormal findings, including breast masses and nipple discharge, and it is more accurate than clinical examination in detecting early breast cancers.
  • Breast cancer can be identified through mammographic features such as a solid mass with or without stellate features, asymmetric thickening of breast tissue, or clustered microcalcifications.
  • To diagnose carcinoma, a core needle biopsy or fine-needle aspiration is usually performed before any treatment begins. In cases where suspicious lymph nodes are present, US-guided fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy is performed to determine the presence of metastatic disease.
  • PET scans are typically done after completion of triple assessment and confirmation of malignancy of breast.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is receiving theophylline as part of her management plan. She reports increased urination since starting the medication. Theophylline causes diuresis by: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenosine antagonism.

 

Theophylline's diuretic effect is primarily due to its antagonism of adenosine receptors, leading to increased renal blood flow and diuresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PDE 4 inhibition: Phosphodiesterase (PDE) 4 inhibition by theophylline is more related to its bronchodilatory effects rather than diuresis.
