Option C. Activation of histone deacetylase: This mechanism is thought to contribute to theophylline's anti-inflammatory effects but is not related to diuresis.

 

Option D. PDE 3 inhibition: This is more related to theophylline's cardiac effects rather than diuresis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of Adverse Effects of Theophylline

questions.text: Which of the following drug must always be available for emergency use in labor ward if a patient is on opioid analgesic? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naloxone

 

Explanation:

 

Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system, thus reversing the effects of the opioid, including respiratory depression. This makes it an essential drug to have on hand in the labor ward when a patient is receiving opioid analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fentanyl: This is an opioid analgesic used for pain management, not for reversing opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: This is another opioid analgesic and would not be used to counteract the effects of other opioids.

 

Option D. Bupivacaine: This is a local anesthetic used for epidural anesthesia, not an opioid antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone must always be available in the labor ward for emergency use when a patient is on opioid analgesic to promptly reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Ref: Page no 546, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Slow waves are generated by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial cells of Cajal

 

Slow waves appear to be caused by complex interactions among the smooth muscle cells and specialized cells, called the interstitial cells of Cajal, that are believed to act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

 

Interstitial cells of Cajal form a network with each other and are interposed between the smooth muscle layers, with synaptic-like contacts to smooth muscle cells and undergo cyclic changes in membrane potential due to unique ion channels that periodically open and produce inward (pacemaker) currents that may generate slow wave activity.

 

The slow waves mainly excite the appearance of intermittent spike potentials, and the spike potentials in turn actually excite the muscle contraction. The slow waves by themselves do not cause muscle contraction except in the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myenteric neurons: Incorrect. Myenteric neurons are part of the enteric nervous system and play a role in regulating gut motility, but they do not generate slow waves.

 

Option B. Smooth muscle cells: Incorrect. Smooth muscle cells respond to slow waves but do not generate them.

 

Option D. Parasympathetic neurons: Incorrect. Parasympathetic neurons modulate gut activity through the autonomic nervous system but do not generate slow waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Slow waves in the gastrointestinal tract are generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, which act as electrical pacemakers for smooth muscle cells.

choices.text: Benedict test and heat coagulation test
Heat coagulation test and Rothera's test

questions.text: Which test will be positive in starvation state in urine? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rothera’s test

 

Detectable levels of ketone bodies in urine (ketonuria) are seen in conditions characterized by increased ketogenesis such as starvation. The urine test done for ketone bodies is the Rothera's test in which formation of a purple ring indicates presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benedict test and heat coagulation test: Used to detect reducing sugars (such as glucose, fructose, and lactose) in urine. In the presence of reducing sugars, Benedict's reagent changes color from blue to green, yellow, or red, depending on the concentration of the sugar. This test is not specific to ketone bodies and is used primarily to diagnose conditions like diabetes mellitus where reducing sugars are present in the urine.

 

Option B. Heat coagulation test: Used to detect proteins in urine. When the urine sample is heated, the presence of proteins causes the formation of a precipitate or cloudiness. This test is used to diagnose conditions like proteinuria, seen in kidney disease, but it does not detect ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gerhardt's test - Ketone bodies in urine.
  • Benedict' test - Reducing sugars.
  • Heat coagulation test - Proteins.
  • Rothera’s test – detect Ketone bodies in urine.

questions.text: Which of the following has autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystic fibrosis

 

Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that an individual needs to inherit two copies of the altered gene (one from each parent) to manifest the condition.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Achondroplasia: Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that having one copy of the altered gene is sufficient to express the condition.

 

Option B. Huntington’s disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern as well, where one copy of the altered gene is enough to cause the disease.

 

Option D. Familial Hypercholesterolemia: Familial Hypercholesterolemia is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, but there are rare cases of autosomal recessive inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

AD (Autosomal Dominant)                                                                                       

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Huntington's disease
  • Lactose Intolerance
  • Marfan Syndrome
  • Myotonic Dystrophy
  • AD Polycystic Kidney Disease
  • Porphyria Variegate

 

AR (Autosomal Recessive)

  • Ataxia Telangiectasia
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Familial Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy
  • Sickle Cell disease
  • Thalassemia
  • Maple Syrup Urine disease
  • Homocystinuria
  • Alkaptonuria
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Albinism
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Wilson's disease
  • Hemochromatosis
  • AR Polycystic Kidney disease
  • Orotic Aciduria
  • Glycogen Storage Diseases
  • All Mucopolysaccharidosis (except Hunter’s)
  • All sphingolipidosis except Fabry’s disease

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 478

choices.text: Blunt force trauma

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive with a bleeding wound on his abdomen, as shown below. The wound edges appear irregular and beveled, particularly on the opposite side of the wound. Based on the appearance and these specific characteristics, identify the type of wound shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Gunshot wound

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a gunshot wound, which is characterized by several distinct features: a central round hole with surrounding soot soiling, burnt hairs (singeing), and punctate skin lesions caused by powder particles, known as tattooing. These findings are indicative of a close-range gunshot injury. Additionally, gunshot wounds may exhibit bevelling of edges, particularly at exit wounds, due to the outward force exerted by the bullet as it exits the body. The combination of soot deposition, singeing, and powder tattooing specifically points to a firearm injury, especially when the muzzle is close enough for these effects to be observed on the skin.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Stab wound: Stab wounds present with sharp, clean edges and are usually slit-like or linear. They do not have the central round hole, soot soiling, singed hairs, or powder tattooing typical of gunshot wounds.

 

B. Blunt force trauma: Blunt force trauma causes contusions, abrasions, and lacerations, without the distinctive central hole, soot, or burnt hair. These injuries are caused by blunt objects, not firearms.

 

D. Incised wound: Incised wounds are caused by sharp instruments, characterized by straight, clean edges and are usually longer than they are deep. They lack the features of soot, singeing, and tattooing seen in gunshot wounds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gunshot wounds can be identified by a central round hole, surrounding soot soiling, singed hairs, punctate lesions from powder particles, and bevelling of wound edges in exit wounds. Recognizing these features is essential for distinguishing gunshot injuries from other types of trauma in clinical and forensic settings.

questions.text:
What is the sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Pulmonary
  2. Aortic
  3. Mitral
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 ➔ 2 ➔ 3
 

The sequence of cardiac sounds as they're perceived on the left side of the chest, from top to bottom, is outlined below:

 

  1. Pulmonary - detected in the second intercostal space.
  2. Aortic - can be heard at the neoaortic region or Erb's point, situated in the second intercostal space.
  3. Mitral - observed at the fifth intercostal space.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall is: Pulmonary (second intercostal space), Aortic (second intercostal space), and Mitral (fifth intercostal space).

choices.text: Light green SF
Orange G
Eosin B

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Papanicolaou stain? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Eosin B

 

Eosin B is not a component of Papanicolaou stain.

 

Papanicolaou stain is the most popular stain used in the practice of histopathology. It is a polychrome stain containing multiple dyes to stain the various components of cells differentially. Papanicolaou stain includes both acidic and basic dyes:

 

The classic form of Pap stain involves five dyes in three solutions:

 

  1. A nuclear stain, hematoxylin, is used to stain cell nuclei.
  2. First OG-6 counterstain. The Orange G is used to stain keratin.
  3. Second EA (Eosin Azure) counterstain, comprising of three dyes
    • Eosin Y stains the superficial epithelial squamous cells, nucleoli, cilia, and red blood cells.
    • Light Green SF yellowish stains the cytoplasm of all other cells.
    • Bismarck brown Y – omitted in contemporary formulations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Light green SF: This dye is used in the Pap stain to color the cytoplasm of various cells green.

 

Option B. Orange G: This dye stains keratin and protein-rich components orange.

 

Option D. Hematoxylin: A nuclear stain used to color cell nuclei blue-purple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosin B is not a component of the Papanicolaou stain, which uses a combination of hematoxylin, Orange G, and Eosin Azure (including Eosin Y and Light Green SF) to differentially stain cellular components.

choices.text: All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule
All killed vaccines under NIS can be given
Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in acute phase
Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling

questions.text: A child suffering from steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the OD for vaccination. Which of the following is true about vaccination in this child? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All killed vaccines under NIS can be given

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, the approach to vaccination must be carefully considered, particularly due to their immunocompromised state from corticosteroid therapy.

 

  • Killed (inactivated) vaccines are safe and can be administered to these children as they do not pose a risk of causing disease. This includes vaccines such as the inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine, and others under the National Immunization Schedule (NIS).
  • Live vaccines should be administered with caution. For children on corticosteroid therapy, live vaccines (e.g., MMR, varicella) are generally avoided unless the child is on low-dose corticosteroids (less than 1 mg/kg/day of prednisone or equivalent). Live virus vaccines are contraindicated in children receiving high doses of steroids or other immunosuppressive therapies like cyclophosphamide or cyclosporine.
  • Vaccination of household contacts: It's crucial to vaccinate healthy household contacts with live vaccines to protect the immunosuppressed child indirectly. However, precautions should be taken to avoid contact with the secretions of recently vaccinated individuals, particularly in the case of live oral vaccines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All live vaccines under NIS can be given as per schedule: This is not accurate as live vaccines should be given with caution or avoided in immunocompromised children, particularly those on high-dose steroids.

 

Option C. Only pneumococcal vaccine should be given to the child in the acute phase: While the pneumococcal vaccine is important, it is not the only vaccine that should be considered. Killed vaccines are generally safe and should be administered according to the vaccination schedule.

 

Option D. Live vaccines are contraindicated in the child's sibling: This is incorrect. Siblings and household contacts should receive live vaccines to reduce the risk of transmitting infections to the immunocompromised child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines under the National Immunization Schedule can be safely administered, while live vaccines should be given with caution depending on the child's immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, frequent vomiting, and watery diarrhea. The patient complaints that his stools emit a faint glow and release mild fumes. The patient reports consuming various food items at a local festival recently. Based on the luminescent nature of the stools (aka Smoky stool syndrome) and the clinical presentation, which substance is most likely responsible for the toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Phosphorus

 

Explanation:

 

Acute phosphorus poisoning is characterized by luminescent stools, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. The luminescent nature of the stools is due to the phosphorescent properties of phosphorus, which can also produce mild fumes, known as "smoky stool syndrome." This unique feature is a hallmark of phosphorus poisoning, often seen when the substance is ingested, either accidentally or intentionally. Phosphorus is commonly found in certain pesticides and fireworks, making exposure possible in various settings, such as festivals.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning typically presents with symptoms such as abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and a garlic-like odor on the breath. Stools in arsenic poisoning are usually greenish or blackish but do not exhibit luminescence.

 

C. Iron: Iron toxicity leads to symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and black or dark green stools due to iron sulfide formation. However, iron poisoning does not cause luminescent stools or the smoky stool syndrome observed with phosphorus poisoning.

 

D. Lead: Lead poisoning is associated with abdominal pain, headache, constipation, and a bluish line on the gums. Stools are generally dark or tarry but do not glow or emit fumes as seen in phosphorus poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphorus poisoning is distinct due to its characteristic luminescent stools, often accompanied by abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea. The luminescence and mild fume release, referred to as "smoky stool syndrome," differentiate it from other toxicities. Other poisoning symptoms include garlic-like breath in arsenic, bluish gum lines in lead, pinpoint pupils in organophosphates, and cherry-red skin in carbon monoxide. Recognizing these signs is crucial for appropriate diagnosis and treatment in toxicological emergencies.

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation

 

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is crucial in the initial evaluation of a patient presenting with syncope, particularly to rule out cardiac causes such as atrial fibrillation, which can lead to episodic reductions in cardiac output and cerebral perfusion. Atrial fibrillation, a common arrhythmia in the elderly, can cause transient episodes of dizziness and loss of consciousness due to irregular and often rapid heart rate leading to ineffective heart pumping.

 

Note - In an elderly w/ first episode of syncope detailed history, clinical exam (cardiac, postural BP, neuro exam), basic investigations (ECG, +/- ECHO) is required

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done: While a CT scan might be considered if there is suspicion of a neurological cause after a thorough clinical evaluation, it is not automatically the next step following a normal ECG, especially in the absence of neurological symptoms or signs suggestive of structural brain disease.

 

Option C. Tilt-table testing: This is generally reserved for cases where recurrent unexplained episodes of syncope occur, particularly when a vasovagal or orthostatic cause is suspected, not typically used after a first episode unless specific indications are present.

 

Option D. Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms: Vestibular neuritis can cause severe vertigo and imbalance but typically does not cause loss of consciousness, making it less likely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients presenting with an acute onset of dizziness and syncope, an ECG is an essential first step to rule out arrhythmic causes such as atrial fibrillation. Additional diagnostic steps should be guided by the findings of the initial evaluation and specific clinical indicators.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Atrial fibrillation/Chap 251

choices.text: Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s
Ceruloplasmin - Hepatolenticular degeneration
High LDH1/LDH2 - Myocardial Infarction
Lipase - Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic marker is incorrectly paired?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s

 

Option A. Defect in Beta glucocerebrosidase is associated with sphingolipid lysosomal storage disorder known as Gaucher’s disease Whereas Von Gierke’s disease is caused due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Hepatolenticular degeneration also known as Wilson’s disease is due to defect in ATP7B gene causing defective biliary excretion of copper and accumulation of copper in liver. There is decrease in plasma ceruloplasmin serving as marker.

 

Option C. In normal person, LDH-2 is more than LDH-1 in serum. BUT in myocardial infarction, LDH-1>>LDH-2. This is known as Flipped ratio of LDH in Myocardial Infarction.

 

Option D. Lipase and amylase are increased in plasma in case of Pancreatitis hence they serve as marker enzymes for pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Beta-glucocerebrosidase is linked to Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s disease, which is caused by a deficiency in Glucose-6-phosphatase. Correct pairing of diagnostic markers and associated conditions is crucial for accurate diagnosis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 64, 167,634
